page.title: 03MANMADE FEATURES MITCHELDEAN
page.content: The Coal Measures in the west of the area are largely covered with forests, with some open areas of disturbed ground from former mining activities. The limestone and sandstone ridges have large fields of pasture, with the best farmland in the Mitcheldean valley. The two main built up areas are the tiny, compact town of Mitcheldean, with its large factory, and the large Forest village of Drybrook. The other main settlements are at Harrow Hill and Plump Hill, both of which are typical "squatter" type settlements, originated by people claiming a right to a piece of land under ancient Forest laws. The result is a landscape of stone cottages dotted haphazardly over the hillsides. Building stone is the Forest stone from the Coal Measures, with Old Red Sandstone used around Mitcheldean.
